Title:
Origin and evolution of birnaviruses revisited: insights from
a new virus of marine zooplankton using advanced phylogenetic
methods
Abstract:
Background Birnaviruses form a distinct family of
double-stranded RNA viruses infecting animal species as different as
vertebrates, mollusks, insects and rotifers. With such a wide host
range, they constitute a good model for studying the adaptation to the
host. Additionally, several lines of evidence link birnaviruses to
positive strand RNA viruses and suggest that phylogenetic analyses may
provide clues about the positive strand to double-stranded RNA virus
transition. Results We characterized the genome of a birnavirus from the
rotifer Branchionus plicalitis, a host phylogenetically very distant
from the other known species targeted by birnaviruses. The rotifer
birnavirus genome exhibits an organization remarkably similar to other
birnaviruses with protein sequence identity scores ranging from 31-36%
and 20-28%, for the capsid and the RNA-dependent RNA-polymerase (RdRp)
proteins, respectively. Using phylogenetic reconstruction methods, we
analyzed the evolutionary pathways within the Birnaviridae family. We
also applied a number of phylogenetic approaches based on structurally
conserved domains/regions of the capsid and RdRp proteins to study
evolutionary relationships between birnavirus, other double-stranded RNA
viruses and positive strand viruses.
